Brother Served in 1st World War

Private 142889 Charles George Servante RAMC enlisted 08/12/1915 discharged 04/03/1915 under Para 392 (XVI) Kings’ Regulations at the age of 33yrs 9mths because of sickness appeared to have never served overseas was awarded the Silver War Badge under Army Order 29 of 1919

comment.author: 69699566@N03
comment._content:
Brother married his Cousin

Amy  Elizabeth Austing is Arthur’s cousin being the daughter of Charles Austing brother to Amelia Austing  who is the mother to both Robert & Arthur Servante

Amy Elizabeth Austing born 27th August 1887 St Pancras London died 1958 age 70yrs
Arthur David Servante born 15th October 1887 Islington died 21st February 1954 Croydon 66yrs old

Amy and Arthur Servante have one son Kenneth Arthur Servante born 15th January 1915 Edmonton died 1982 Bromley Kent 67yrs old

comment._content: ENOUGH IS ENOUGH!!  How far back into this man's genealogy are you going to go?

comment.author: 69699566@N03
comment._content:
The above family history gives anyone a good insight into the real life that Walter Harold Servante would have had outside the day he put on his uniform and went to war.

The above details of his family are all very ordinary people who lived and worked their lives in the north east of London with strong links to the printing world of Fleet Street and they all played as much part in his life and he would of in theirs and would of continued to do so if Walter had not been killed

comment.author: 69699566@N03
comment._content:
READANDWEEP Walters family history may not be of interest to you

But the above is important when it comes to Walter's family and this shows that Walter is not just a face in an old photograph and one line of words put on a memorial stone

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content: Thank you Family Historian for your in depth research. The men in these sets had real lives just as we do today. It is great to see you bringing in Walter's family and social history to this page -- in addition to the military history comments. Thank you.

comment.author: 69798423@N03
comment._content:
Walter landed in France on 20th January 1915.

SDGW Info:

Name: Walter Harold Servante
Residence: Hornsey
Death Date: 16 Apr 1917
Death Location: France & Flanders
Enlistment Location: London
Rank: Sergeant
Regiment: London Regiment
Battalion: 9th (County of London) Battalion (Queen Victorias Rifles)
Number: 390521
Type of Casualty: Died of wounds
Theatre of War: Western European Theatre

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
Queen Victoria’s Rifles were 9th (County of London) Battalion London Regiment.  This was a Territorial infantry battalion.  It mobilised on 4th August 1914, at 56 Davies Street, Berkeley Square, London on the outbreak of war and additional enlistments were welcomed at the Davies Street recruiting office from 6th August.  After training at Pirbright and Crowborough, 9th Londons disembarked at Le Havre in France on 5th November 1914.  The Battalion was initially assigned to 13th Brigade in 5th Division until 10th February 1916 when it was sent to 169th Brigade in 56th (London) Division.
Queen Victoria’s Rifles were notably engaged in the battle for Hill 60 near Ypres, 20th–21st April 1916, during which a QVR platoon commander, 2Lt G H Wolley QVR, won a Victoria Cross.  12 officers and 180 other ranks of the QVR were killed and wounded in this action. 
After trench duties on the Somme, QVR moved up to Arras with 56th Division at the beginning of April 1917 and were committed to the First Battle of the Scarpe, 9th-14th April 1917, as part of the wider Arras offensive which included the Canadian attack on Vimy Ridge.  The division captured the fortified village of Neuville-Vitasse and pressed on to gain the Wancourt Line, with a German trench complex known as the Monchyriegel, anchored on Monchy-le-Preux, as their objective.  However several battalions in 56th Division are recorded as suffering over 300 casualties and it was probably during this fighting that Sergeant Servante was wounded.
The IWM has microfilmed the diaries of Cpl J P Fitch MM of 9th Londons (Jan-Oct 1916) and of Lt W H T Clements of 2nd Londons who was in 169th Brigade Feb 1916-Jan 1918.//
